skills.name: Write a recurring decimal with a double digit recurring pattern as a fraction (US)
Write a fraction with a double digit denominator as a recurring decimal (US)

explanations.A: I think you have used the method for when just the 洧 is being repeated. Here the 洧녷 and 洧 are both being repeated.
explanations.B: Multiplying by 100 we would have 洧녷洧.洧녷洧륋롐뢣롐륋롐뢣롐륋롐뢣롐륋롐... Subtracting one lot of 0.洧녷洧륋롐뢣롐륋롐뢣롐륋롐... will leave us with 99 lots equal to 洧녷洧. Divide by 99 to get 1 lot equals 洧녷洧/99
explanations.C: I think you have tried to use the method for when a single digit is being repeated. Remember we multiply by 100 when two digits are being repeated.
explanations.D: Not quite. Remember when we have two digits being repeated we do 100 lots of the value take away 1 lot of the value. How many lots will we have left?

explanations.A: I think you have used the method for when just the 洧녽 is being repeated. Here the 洧논 and 洧녽 are both being repeated.
explanations.B: I think you have tried to use the method for when a single digit is being repeated. Remember we multiply by 100 when two digits are being repeated.
explanations.C: Multiplying by 100 we would have 洧논洧녽.洧논洧녽洧논洧녽洧논洧녽洧논洧녽洧논... Subtracting one lot of 0.洧논洧녽洧논洧녽洧논洧녽洧논... will leave us with 99 lots equal to 洧논洧녽. Divide by 99 to get 1 lot equals 洧논洧녽/99
explanations.D: Not quite. Remember when we have two digits being repeated we do 100 lots of the value take away 1 lot of the value. How many lots will we have left?

explanations.A: This is 0.777777..., but we have both 0 and 7 being repeated. Remember when two digits are being repeated we do 100 lots of the decimal subtract 1 lot of the decimal.
explanations.B: 100 lots of the number is 07.070707... Subtracting 1 lot gives us 99 lots equal to 7. Therefore 1 lot is 7/99
explanations.C: 7/100 is 0.07, but both 0 and 7 are being repeated in the decimal. Remember when two digits are being repeated we do 100 lots of the decimal subtract 1 lot of the decimal.
explanations.D: I think you've used the repeating number as the denominator. Remember when two digits are being repeated we do 100 lots of the decimal subtract 1 lot of the decimal.

explanations.A: 5/100 is 0.05, but both 0 and 5 are being repeated in the decimal. Remember when two digits are being repeated we do 100 lots of the decimal subtract 1 lot of the decimal.
explanations.B: This is 0.555555..., but we have both 0 and 5 being repeated. Remember when two digits are being repeated we do 100 lots of the decimal subtract 1 lot of the decimal.
explanations.C: I think you've used the repeating number as the denominator. Remember when two digits are being repeated we do 100 lots of the decimal subtract 1 lot of the decimal.
explanations.D: 100 lots of the number is 05.05050505... Subtracting 1 lot gives us 99 lots equal to 5. Therefore 1 lot is 5/99

explanations.A: Using short division 61/99 = 0.616161.... Alternatively you may remember that a denominator of 99 creates a 2 digit recurring decimal.
explanations.B: You're correct that a denominator of 99 gives a recurring decimal. Just double check your division to see which numbers repeat.
explanations.C: You're correct that a denominator of 99 gives a recurring decimal. Just double check your division to see which numbers repeat.
explanations.D: This is 61/100, but we have 61/99. Remember a denominator of 99 will give a recurring decimal. Try doing a division to see which digits are repeated.

explanations.A: Almost, but you have given a terminating decimal here. Remember a denominator of 99 gives recurring decimal. Try dividing to find the repeating decimals.

explanations.A: 41/100 is 0.41, but both 4 and 1 are being repeated in the decimal. Remember when two digits are being repeated we do 100 lots of the decimal subtract 1 lot of the decimal.
explanations.B: This is 0.4444444..., but we have both 4 and 1 being repeated. Remember when two digits are being repeated we do 100 lots of the decimal subtract 1 lot of the decimal.
explanations.C: I think you have used the method for 0.4111111... Remember when two digits are being repeated we do 100 lots of the decimal subtract 1 lot of the decimal.
explanations.D: 100 lots of the number is 41.41414141... Subtracting 1 lot gives us 99 lots equal to 41. Therefore 1 lot is 41/99
